an3.128:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana.
an3.128:4.2: Then the Buddha got dressed in the morning and, taking his bowl and robes, entered Benares for alms.
an3.128:4.3: While the Buddha was walking for alms near the cow-hitching place at the wavy leaf fig, he saw a disgruntled monk who was looking for pleasure in external things, unmindful, without situational awareness or samādhi, with straying mind and undisciplined faculties.
an3.128:5.2: If you’re bitter, corrupted by the stench of rotting flesh, flies will, without a doubt, plague and infest you.”
an3.128:5.3: Hearing this advice of the Buddha, that monk came to his senses.
an3.128:5.4: Then, after the meal, on his return from alms-round, the Buddha told the mendicants what had happened. …
an3.128:7.4: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha:
an3.128:7.6: What is the ‘stench of rotting flesh’?
an3.128:8.2: ill will is the stench of rotting flesh;
an3.128:8.3: and bad, unwholesome thoughts are the flies.
an3.128:8.4: If you’re bitter, corrupted by the stench of rotting flesh, flies will, without a doubt, plague and infest you.”
an3.128:9.1: “When your eyes and ears are unguarded,
an3.128:9.2: and you’re not restrained in your sense faculties,
an3.128:10.2: corrupted by the stench of rotting flesh,
an3.128:11.2: if they don’t find serenity in themselves,
an3.128:11.4: has flies as their only followers.
